required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Risk Factors for Long-term Opioid Use
clinical_study.official_title: OPIOID USE AMONG PATIENTS WITH PAIN SYNDROMES COMMONLY SEEKING SURGICAL CONSULTATION

brief_summary.textblock:
Surgeons often see patients with pain to exclude organic pathology and consider surgical treatment. We examined factors associated with long-term opioid therapy among patients with foot/ankle, anorectal, and temporomandibular joint pain to aid clinical decision making.
Using the IBM MarketScanÂ® Research Database, we conducted a retrospective cohort analysis of patients aged 18-64 with a clinical encounter for foot/ankle, anorectal, or temporomandibular joint pain (January 2007-September 2015). Multivariable logistic regression was used to estimate adjusted odds ratios for factors associated with long-term opioid therapy, including age, sex, geographic region, pain condition, psychiatric diagnoses, and surgical procedures in the previous year.

arm_group.description: Patients presenting with temporomandibular joint pain.
Patients presenting with foot and ankle pain.

intervention.intervention_name: No intervention - retrospective observational cohort study

study_pop.textblock: adult patients enrolled in private health insurance included within the Marketscan database, who generated at least one insurance claim for anorectal, foot/ankle, or TMJ pain.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18-64 years old
- at least one encounter for anorectal, foot/ankle, or TMJ pain
- Marketscan continuous enrollment for 1 year prior and 1 year after the index pain encounter
